Crimes.Crime_Name: Serious criminality under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether humanitarian and compassionate grounds must be considered before referring a permanent resident to an admissibility hearing for serious criminality
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), s. 44(1)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Correia was convicted of importing cocaine, a serious crime under s. 36(1)(a) of IRPA. The immigration officer and delegate based their report and referral solely on the conviction and sentence.
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the referral decision
Crimes.Court_Ruling: The referral process complied with IRPA; humanitarian considerations are not required at the referral stage for serious criminality
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Inadmissibility due to serious criminality under s. 36(1)(a) of IRPA
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Inadmissibility determined by conviction and sentence; no discretion to consider humanitarian factors at referral stage
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Conviction and sentence for an indictable offense punishable by a maximum term of imprisonment of at least 10 years
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Referral to admissibility hearing without consideration of humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not applicable – based on criminal conviction
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Criminal conviction record and sentencing information
Crimes.Application_Basis: Factual basis of conviction and sentence
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Official court documents confirming conviction and sentence
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Set aside the referral and prevent removal
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Reporting inadmissible permanent residents is mandatory upon conviction for serious criminality
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: None found – sufficient evidence of conviction and sentence
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: Humanitarian circumstances not considered relevant at this procedural stage
Crimes.Cause_Description: Mr. Correia's conviction for importing cocaine led to designation as inadmissible on grounds of serious criminality
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: None – conviction was final and undisputed
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Permanent resident status does not exempt from removal for serious criminality
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Conviction and sentence established as per statutory requirements
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Statutory obligation to refer based on conviction; no discretion to consider H&C at referral stage
Crimes.Decision_Making_Body: Immigration Officer, Minister’s Delegate, Immigration Division, Federal Court
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Objective application of IRPA provisions regarding serious criminality

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Controlled Drugs and Substances Act (implied), IRPA s. 36(1)(a)
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Whether failure to consider humanitarian and compassionate factors violated procedural fairness
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; removal order upheld
Crimes.Review_Mechanism: Judicial review under the IRPA framework
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration Officer, Minister’s Delegate, Immigration Division
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Nature of offense (importation of controlled substance), severity of penalty
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issue: No dispute over authenticity or accuracy of conviction
Crimes.Procedural_Requirement: Mandatory reporting under s. 44(1) of IRPA after conviction
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Public safety risk due to drug importation
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Serious criminality defined under IRPA based on conviction for offense punishable by 10+ years
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Immigration Officer, Delegate, Immigration Division, Federal Court
Crimes.Outcome: Removal from Canada ordered and enforced
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Final criminal conviction for importation of cocaine
Crimes.Charter_Issues: Potential section 7 (life, liberty, security) arguments raised but not successful

Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issues: Allegation that H&C considerations should have been included; rejected by court
